Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Opportunities in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) and the Division of Materials Research (DMR) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site led by Sarah Larsen at the University of Iowa. The research projects supported in this site are in areas of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Undergraduates will be recruited to this site primarily from institutions that lack infrastructure to support undergraduate research, including students from underrepresented groups. The site will support ten students per summer in a ten week program. A sample of the projects that undergraduates will work on include: (1) the development of new synthetic routes to nanostructured inorganic catalysts; (2) the study of the applications and implications of nanoscience and nanotechnology in environmental processes; (3) the applications of nanocrystalline zeolites in environmental remediation, catalysis and drug delivery; (4) the production of self-sterilizing coatings using magnetic nanoparticles; (5) the study of the reactivity of nanoparticle iron minerals in water and soil and (6) the atomic-force microscopy study of single-crystal reactivity of organic nanocrystals. In addition to conducting research during the summer, the students participating in this program will participate in a number of professional development activities, including a technical communication workshop, a weekly seminar series, as well as additional formal and informal mentoring events.

Young scientists need exposure to modern research methods and tools as part of their training. This REU site aims to provide cutting-edge research training in the chemical sciences, with a strong emphasis on nanoscience and nanotechnology, especially in its interaction with the environment. The diverse student cohort participating in research at this site will be well-prepared for graduate school, and eventual employment as part of the country's technical workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology at the University of Iowa was funded consecutively for research programs during the summers of 2008-2013. This report covers the grant period from 2011-2013.  38 undergraduate students participated in the REU program on Nanoscience and Nanotechnology at the University of Iowa from 2010-2013 with funding from the NSF.  The average number of applicants was >100/year. Of the total number of participants from 2011-2013, 15 (39%) were underrepresented minority students and 19 (50%) were women.  17 students (45%) were from institutions that do not offer graduate degrees in chemistry or engineering and therefore, have limited research opportunities. Of the 38 student participants from 2011-2013 who have graduated from college, 16 (80%) enrolled in graduate or professional degree programs after graduating and 4(20%) are employed in industry.  REU participants from 2011-2013 were co-authors on 5 journal manuscripts.  The publication venues are high quality, peer-reviewed scientific journals which attests to the high quality of the REU research experience. Each year, REU students filled out program evaluation surveys at the end of the program. There were 20 questions about the program that were rated from 1-6 with 1=strongly agree, 2=moderately agree, 3=slightly agree, 4=slightly disagree, 5=moderately disagree and 6=strongly disagree.  The average of the student responses (2011-2013) over the 20 questions was 1.5.   Some sample questions and average responses are provided below:

“Overall, participating in this program was beneficial to me”- average=1.0

 “I have a better understanding of scientific research.” average=1.3

“The REU program has added to my knowledge of nanoscience and nanotechnology” average=1.2

These evaluations indicate that students have a meaningful REU experience at the University of Iowa in the Nano-REU program. 

 

Broader Impacts

The REU participants were involved in cutting edge research projects related to nanoscience and nanotechnology research and also participated in research ethics, safety, graduate school information, networking and technical communication sessions. Special emphasis was placed on recruiting students with limited research opportunities, women and underrepresented minorities.  From 2011-2013, 39% of the REU participants were from underrepresented groups and 50% were women.  Many of the former REU participants presented their research at conferences and/or published in scientific journals.  80% of former REU participants who have graduated from college have gone on to graduate (70%) or professional degree programs (10%).
